metadata.title: Effects of nano-particles on failure process and microstructural properties of recycled aggregate concrete

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Effects of nano-particles on failure process and microstructural properties of recycled aggregate concrete
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.03.051 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: Centre for Built Infrastructure Research, School of Civil & Environmental Engineering, University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, NS Australia.
E-mail address: wengui.li@uts.edu.au (W. Li).
Wengui Li a,f,⇑, Chu Long b, Vivian W.Y. Tam c,d, Chi-Sun Poon e, Wen Hui Duan f aCentre for Built Infrastructure Research, School of Civil & Environmental Engineering, University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, NSW 2007, Australia bCollege of Civil Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, Hunan 410082, PR China c School of Computing, Engineering and Mathematics, Western Sydney University, Penrith, NSW 2751, Australia dCollege of Civil Engineering, Shenzhen University, PR China eDepartment of Civil and Environmental Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Kowloon, Hong Kong, China fDepartment of Civil Engineering, Monash University, Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia
h i g h l i g h t s
Failure process of RAC was influenced by the relative strength between new and old cement mortars. Colloidal NS could enter into ITZ regions in RAC to increased hydration products by secondary chemical reaction. Powdered NL could not enhance the compressive strength of RAC due to the particles agglomeration. Colloidal NS could effectively reduced porosity and water absorption of RAC.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 23 November 2016 Received in revised form 13 February 2017 Accepted 8 March 2017
Keywords: Recycled aggregate concrete (RAC) Nano-particles Micro-cracks Interfacial transition zone (ITZ) Water absorption Microstructural properties
a b s t r a c t
The effects of nano-particles including nano-silica (NS) and nano-limestone (NL) on the crack propagation and microstructure properties of recycled aggregate concrete (RAC) were experimentally investigated in this study. The crack initiation and propagation of nano-particles modified RAC with different nanoparticle modification were evaluated using digital image correlation technique (DIC). The microstructures and porosity of interfacial transition zones (ITZ) in nano-modified RAC were also examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP). It was found that the micro-cracks were typically derived from relatively weak ITZs in RAC, and then progressively propagated along the compressive loading direction. The meso-crack developments eventually led to final splitting failure. The results indicated that compared to NL, NS was more effective in improving the microstructure properties and enhance the mechanical strength of RAC. The porosity and water absorption of RAC were obviously reduced by the NS incorporation. However, due to particles agglomeration, NL could not effectively improve the microstructure of RAC for further enhancing the RAC mechanical properties. Furthermore, in terms of severe particles agglomeration, NL was even detrimental to the mechanical strength of RAC especially at the late-age.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
W 2007,

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The study on recycled aggregate concrete (RAC) have become a hot topic in the field of construction material. A lot of researchers realized that RAC can effectively recover waste into useful resources. However, compared to ordinary concrete, there are still some shortcomings of RAC for practical applications in terms of mechanical properties [1–5], which is one of the major factors limiting RAC in structural applications. To address this concern, a series of research studies had been conducted to develop methods to improve the RAC mechanical performance. Because the properties of the recycled aggregate to a large extent determines the performances of the RAC [6,7], increasing number of studies were carried out to improve the quality of recycled aggregate. These methods include microwave heating [8], chemical immersion [9], biological precipitation [10,11], carbonization [12,13], and surface treatment of recycled aggregate [14–17]. However, more effective methods are still needed to achieve better mechanical properties for RAC. For the failure mechanism of RAC, previous studies [18–21] have confirmed that the mechanical properties of RAC is closely related to the properties of the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) between new cement mortar and recycled aggregate [22–24].
Nano-particles can act as nuclei for cement phases, further promoting cement hydration process due to their high reactivity as filler and densifying the microstructure, thereby, and leading to reduce porosity number of nano-particle has been studied for incorporating in cement and concrete including nano-silica (NS) [25–27], nano-limestone (NL) [28–29], nano-metallic oxide [30– 32], graphene oxide [33–35], carbon nano-tubes [36–37]. Two nano-particle types, NS and NL, are the most commonly used in cementitious material applications. Currently, there are typically two methods which have been reported for producing nanosized silica and limestone particles: (i) high energy milling of raw material (top-down approach); and (ii) chemical synthesis (bottom-up approach) [38,39]. Previous studies usually showed that they can act as nuclei for promoting cement hydration process. These nano-particles can also act as physical fillers for densifying the microstructure of the cement mortar and ITZs in RAC. Nanoparticle has advantages in improving the mechanical properties of cementitious composites. The modifications of NS and NL have been demonstrated in NAC [26,28,29]. NS exhibits strong pozzolanic effect, which can promote the secondary hydration of cement, i.e. pozzolanic reaction, generating further calcium silicate hydrates (C-S-H), and fills the pore structures. On the other hand, NL has a strong effect of crystal nucleus and physical filling effects which can largely improve the concrete microstructure. RAC which is more porous than natural aggregate concrete is more likely to be improved by nano-particles. But further studies on the failure mechanism of nano-particles modified RAC are still necessary.
In this study, NS and NL at different dosages were used to enhance the properties of RAC. The effects of nano-particle on the mechanical strength and crack propagation of RAC were evaluated with incorporation dosages and mixing methods. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) techniques were used to analyze the failure mechanism and microstructure properties of the nano-modified RAC with NS and NL. The related results can provide an insight into and enhancing RAC properties and promoting structural applications.

sections.heading: 2.1. Sample preparation
sections.text: Ordinary Portland cement (OPC 42.5) was used in the experiments, and the chemical compositions are shown in Table 1. The fine aggregate used was common natural river sands, and the fineness modulus was 2.6. Natural gravel with continuous gradation from 5 to 26.5 mm was chosen as natural coarse aggregate. It had water absorption of 0.96% and bulk density of 1,395 kg/m3. The recycled coarse aggregate (RCA) was obtained from the demolition of wasted concrete at the Shanghai Port wharf, China. The RCA had a water absorption value of 6.30%, and a bulk density of 1290 kg/m3. The powdered NL was purchased from Xuan Cheng Jing Rui New Material Co., Ltd, China. The colloidal NS was purchased from Zhejiang Yuda Chemical Co., LTD, China. The physiochemical properties of the nano-particles (powdered NL and colloidal NS) used are shown in Tables 2 and 3, respectively. A naphthalene based superplasticizer was used to improve the RAC workability and serve as the dispersant of NL powder in solution. After NL powder was mixed with a small amount of water. Then NL solution was subjected to ultrasonication to improve the dispersion by a Sonics Vibra-Cell vcx-500 ultrasonic processor (Vibra-Cell-Sonics & Materials, Inc.) with an energy intensity of 40,000 J with amplitude of 80% and pulse of 4 s.

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental program
sections.text:
The RCA was used to replace the natural coarse aggregate by weight at 30%. According to NS dosage (1.0 and 2.0% by weight of cement) and two different mixing methods, NS-RAC was divided into S1, S2, S3 and S4. According to the different NL dosages (1.0 and 2.0% by weight of cement) and superplasticizer addition (1.0% by weight of cement), NL-RAC was divided into L1, L2, L3 and L4. The compressive strength of the RAC was tested after 7- day and 28-day standard curing at 20 ± 2 C and relative humidity of 90 ± 5%. Concrete cubes of 150 150 150 mm were cast using different dosages of nano-particles (powdered NL and colloidal NS), as shown in Table 4. Three cubes were tested to measure the compressive strength. To investigate the failure process of RAC, some cubes were cut into slices of 150 150 30 mm for uniaxial compression test. To study the effect of nano-particles on the RAC, the natural aggregate concrete (NAC), RAC, nanosilica modified RAC (NS-RAC) and nano-limestone modified RAC (NL-RAC) were prepared by an effective water to cement ratio of 0.5 for comparison.
Due to the high water absorption of RCA, an additional amount of water was added to assure the same effective water to cement ratio for all the nano-particles modified RAC specimens. The additional water was calculated by the water absorbed from air-dry condition to saturated-surface-dried (SSD) condition [5,23]. There were two mixing methods (Method 1 and Method 2) for the RAC preparation, as shown in Fig. 1. For the first mixing method with the insight from the two-stage mixing method developed by Tam et al. [5], RCA and nano-particles were firstly mixed for 60 s, and subsequently mixed for another 30 s with half of the mixing water added. Then, cement, sand and the remaining water were added and mixed for a further 60 s. For the second mixing method, RCA,

cement and sand were firstly mixed for 30 s, and subsequently mixed for another 60 s with half of the mixing water. Secondly, nano-particles and the remaining water were added and mixed for 60 s.
The compressive experiment on nano-particles modified RAC was conducted the in Key Laboratory of Building Safety and Energy Efficiency, Hunan University, Ministry of Education of China. The current experimental system consists of three parts: a digitally controlled servo-hydraulic loading system with a capacity of 6000 kN, a computer vision DIC system and image analysis software. The loading was applied with a displacement control and
the loading rate was controlled at 0.04 mm/min. The image records of the whole front surface of RAC specimen was captured with a camera of the DIC during testing. Two Teflon sheets of 0.2 mm thickness were inserted between the specimen and the machine loading plates for reducing the frictional shear constraints. Strain contour maps were produced to analyze the crack initiation and propagation during compressive loading. The SEM (FEI Quanta 200 FEG) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy was used to examine the microstructure of ITZ regions. The samples are small fractured pieces of hardened RAC samples obtained after mechanical strength testing and soaked in acetone to stop the
hydration (old and new ITZs in RAC). The MIP is based on the principle that mercury, a typical non-wetting liquid, can only intrude a porous material if a certain pressure is applied on the measured samples. MIP samples around the new ITZ region of each type of concrete were broken into several small particles with diameters of 3.5–5.0 mm and soaked in acetone to stop further hydration. Then they were dried at 60 C in oven for 24 h before MIP examination. The experiments were carried out under low pressure of 0.28 MPa and high pressure of 413.70 MPa respectively. A glass tube with the sample and mercury in was subsequently placed in a low and high pressure analysis port [40]. For the water absorption measurement, the three replicated samples of each concrete type were cured in standard curing condition for 28 days. After this, they were taken out from the curing room and allowed to dry superficially for about 2 h in the laboratory. Their cube surface was subsequently coated with epoxy adhesive paint and the next day they were put in a well-ventilated oven at 105 C for 2 days. At the end of this period, the samples were taken out from the oven, were wrapped with thin plastic foil and stored in the laboratory for 2 days [41,42]. Water capillary absorption measurements were started at when the samples cooled from oven. The samples were put in a water tank with the bottom-as-cast surface immersed up to 2 mm in the water for a period of 6 h. The water level in the tank was kept constant during this period. The samples were taken out from the water tank at intervals of 10 min, 30 min, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 h were weighed on a 0.01 g balance, after being wiped with a dry paper towel.

sections.heading: 3.1. Crack propagation
sections.text:
The crack pattern of nano-modified RAC was observed at different stages of compressive loading. The RAC specimens of 150 150 30 mm were tested to investigate the real-time crack propagation under compressive loading using digital image correlation (DIC) technique [43,44]. Under uniaxial compression, RAC specimen can be considered as a state of plane stress, the 2D-
(a) 30 % of peak load (b) 60 % of p
Fig. 2. Crack propagation of RAC usin
digital image correlation was capable of examining the twodimensional cracking propagation. The horizontal strain distribution on the surface of the RAC was presented as a series of gray scale maps. Based on the real-time record of crack propagations captured by DIC, it was found that the failure processes of the RAC specimens were similar. But compared to the crack propagations, the crack evolutions in each of the stages were different for the RAC with different nano-particle modifications. During the first stage, when the compressive load was 30% of the peak load, the stress level was relatively low. Micro-crack initiations surrounding the recycled coarse aggregate (RCA) were not very obvious, as shown in Fig. 2. Only a few micro-cracks appeared because the tensile stress was greater than the bonding strength between the cement mortar and RCA. But the micro-cracks were in a stable state. During the second stage, when the load level was greater than 30%, but less than 70% of the peak load, the micro-cracks around RCA were produced and gradually developed, as shown in Fig. 3. Among these cracks, the more longitudinal cracks were found than transverse cracks. During the third stage, when the load level was greater than 70%, but less than 90% of the peak load, the width and the amount of cracks dramatically increased as shown in Fig. 4. The cracks gradually propagated from the ITZs to the cement mortar areas in RAC. Finally, instantaneous crushing failure was observed when the cracks developed vertically through the RAC specimens generally along the loading direction. Overall, according to the crack propagation patterns with the RAC specimens prepared with different nano-particles (NS and NL), it was found that the micro-crack initiation was obviously affected by the relative strength of the new and old cement mortars. The crack propagation and development pattern information of the nanomodified RAC at different loading levels during compression was captured with the DIC strain grayscale images. The image analysis software (Optical Fringe Pattern Analysis) was then used to calculate the displacements and strain distribution over the specimen surface. The results were found consistent with the previous results [19,45]. The micro-crack initiation and development were captured much earlier by the DIC than by the naked human eye. As for the RAC, most cracks propagated through both the ITZ
eak load (c) 80 % of peak load
g grayscale map of strain by DIC.
regions and old cement mortar due to the comparable strength between the new and the old cement mortars, as shown in Fig. 2. With respect to NL-RAC, most cracks propagated through the ITZ regions and the old cement mortar because the agglomeration effect made the ITZs even weaker when NL was added, as shown in Fig. 3. For NS-RAC, the RCA was obviously crushed and the cracks developed through old cement mortar, which could be attributed to the much stronger bonding strength between the new and old cement mortars when NS was added, as shown in Fig. 4. Therefore, it can be concluded that the crack initiation and propagation patterns of RAC under compression was dependent on the relative
strengths of new and old ITZs, which were affected by the nanoparticles modification.

sections.heading: 3.2. Nano-particles modification
sections.text:
From Fig. 5, it was found that the NS-modified RAC (S1, S2, S3 and S4) exhibited higher 7-day compressive strength compared to both RAC and NAC. Compared to the RAC without nanoparticles, the improvement of compressive strength varied from 20.7% to 24.9%. As shown in Fig. 6, the 28-day compressive strength also increased by 14.6% to 21.6% when NS was added.
The compressive strengths of NS-RAC cured after both 7-day and 28-day were also evidently higher than those NAC. The results showed that NS was more effective to improve the early-age strength of RAC than the late-age strength. The result also confirmed that the NS significantly enhanced the compressive strength by promoting secondary cement hydration. Therefore, it implies that the NS increased the C-S-H gel formation as a result of the reaction between NS and calcium hydroxide (CH) and filled the spaces in the C-S-H crystal lattice as physical nano-fillers [46,47]. By comparing the 7-day and 28-day compressive strengths of RAC, it was found that at the same NS dosage, there was no distinct difference between the mixing Method 1 and 2. This means that the mixing methods did not obviously affect the NS modification of RAC, because Method 1 could not evidently densify the microstructure and increased the compressive strength by premixing the RCA and nano-particles. This indicates that NS modification of RAC was mainly due to the secondary chemical reaction, while just slightly due to the physical filling effect [5].
However, for the NL modification, it was found that the 7-day compressive strengths of L1 and L2 were higher than that of RAC, but the 7-day compressive strengths of L3 and L4 were slightly lower than that of RAC. On the other hand, the 28-day compressive strengths of the NL-modified RAC were relatively lower than that of RAC without nano-particles. This may be attributed to the poor
dispersion of NL, which usually causes particles agglomeration in RAC. The result also implied that the superplasticizer can somewhat reduce the NL agglomeration. As the NL was not able to enhance the strength of RAC, NL actually played a negative role
in the RAC modification because of the poor dispersion of NL powder. Therefore, the physical filling effect and effect of crystal nucleus of NL seemed not significant because of the nanoparticles agglomeration involved. Although superplasticizer seemed to improve the NL dispersion in RAC to a certain degree, alternative effective methods are still needed to be explored to improve the dispersion of NL powder for the modification.

sections.heading: 3.3. Microstructure properties
sections.text:
The microstructures of new and old ITZs in RAC were characterized by SEM as shown in Fig. 7. It was found that compared to RAC, both the NS- and NL-modified RAC had denser microstructures and less micro-cracks in ITZs, especially in the NS-RAC. The results showed that NS rendered a better modification effect compared to NL in terms of strength improvement and porosity reduction. From Fig. 8, it was found that there are more micro-cracks in the
new ITZ of NL-modified RAC than the NS-modified RAC. The results showed that for NS-RAC, both the new and old cement mortar appeared denser. But for NL-RAC, there were still some microcracks in the cement mortar. NS was more likely to enter into ITZs to promote the chemical reaction and accelerate the hydration process. As a result, more hydration products such as C-S-H gels were found and both the new and old ITZs became significantly denser. However, for NL, due to the poor dispersion, it was more difficult to the NL particle to enter into the ITZs to accelerate chemical reactions.

sections.heading: 3.4. Water absorption
sections.text: The transport properties and capillary absorption were greatly influenced by the microstructures and porosities of the concrete specimens. The water absorption values for nano-particle modified RAC are shown in Fig. 9. It is found that the water absorption values of RAC, NL-RAC and NS-RAC after 6 h were 4.52%, 4.00% and 3.62%, respectively. The RAC exhibited the highest water absorption, while NS-RAC had the lowest water absorption. This suggested that under the same conditions, both NS and NL incorporations can reduce the water absorption by improving microstructures and decreasing porosity in RAC. It should be noted that the reduction in the water absorption of the NS-modified RAC was more significant when compared to the NL-modified RAC. Although, the agglomeration significantly reduced the bonding strength of ITZ, and eventually improvement in compressive strength of NL-RAC, NL was still effective in densify the microstructures as physical fillers.

sections.heading: 3.5. Porosity and pore size distribution
sections.text:
It showed that the total porosities of ITZs regions in RAC modified with NS and NL became obviously less than that of RAC. From Table 5, the total porosity of RAC was 12.00%, while NL-RAC and
NS-RAC exhibited very similar results of around 8.82% and 9.06%, respectively. This result can be used to explain why RAC, NL-RAC and NS-RAC exhibited increasing trend in the water absorption. The higher porosity usually results in higher water absorption or transport properties. Furthermore, the porosity with diameter greater than 1000 nm was 40.4% in RAC, while the porosity of NL-RAC and NS-RAC were 48.8% and 27.1%, respectively. Compare to the RAC without nano-particles, the amount of pores greater than 1000 nm were reduced by 13.3% for NS-RAC, but were increased by 8.4% for NL-RAC. This indicates that the NS can improve the microstructures and reduce the porosity of NS-RAC, while NL seems not as effective as in reducing the large-size pores NL-RAC. However, the NL significantly reduced the pores with size from 50 to 1000 nm by 13% in NL-RAC, while the NS adversely increased the pores in range of 50–1000 nm by 40% in NS-RAC. It implies that the NL is more effective in reducing the mediumsize pores in the ITZs than the NS in nano-particle modified RAC.
The measured pores can be divided into five size ranges, including gel micro-pores with diameter less than 10 nm, meso-pores of 10–50 nm, capillary pores of 50 nm to 1.0 lm and macro-pore larger than 1.0 lm [48,49]. The RAC, NL-RAC and NS-RAC exhibited different ranges in the pores size distribution and cumulative porosity, as shown in Fig. 10. The porosity of NS-RACwas very close
to that of NL-RAC, but the pore size distribution was very different. It was found that the NS-RAC had a very narrow porosity distribution peak and the lowest critical pore width value. The threshold and critical pore width can provide a useful indicator of mechanical strengths because they played an important influence on the microstructure characteristics of the RAC. It was observed that the most probable pore for RAC, NL-RAC and NS-RAC were 28,070 nm, 188,600 nm and 132.5 nm, respectively. The results showed that the pores of ITZ were mainly composed of capillary pore (from 50 nm to 1.0 lm) and macro-pores (larger than 1.0 lm) in RAC and NL-RAC, while in NS-RAC, capillary-pores (from 50 nm to 1.0 lm) accounted for most of the total pores. Therefore, the NS was effective in improving the microstructure and significantly reduced the macro-scale pores in RAC, but somewhat increased the capillary-pores. However, although the NL partially reduced the capillary-pores by the physical filling effect, but compared to the RAC without nano-particles, it could not significantly reduce the macro-pores. Therefore, NL was not able to reduce the total porosity of RAC and increase the compressive strength, which was consistent with the compressive strength results.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The effects of nano-particles on the crack propagation and microstructural properties of RAC were experimentally investigated in this study. Based on results, the following conclusion can be drawn:
(1) The micro-crack typically initiated in the weak ITZs of RAC with different nano-particle modifications. The initiation location was affected by the relative bonding strength between new and old cement mortar. The micro-cracks propagated along the loading direction, finally leading to wholly splitting failure. (2) The micro-crack initiation and propagation provided fundamental information for the failure mechanism of RAC. When the strength of new ITZ was inferior to that of old ITZ, the first observable crack usually appeared at the new ITZ region. But when the strength of the new ITZ was higher than that of old ITZ, the first micro-crack mostly occurred at the old ITZ. (3) Colloidal NS could easily enter into the ITZs of RAC to accelerate hydration process and increase the hydration products by further chemical reactions. Thus, the further product growth filled the pores and voids with physical filling effect, then significantly improved the microstructure properties and enhanced the RAC compressive strength. The compressive strength of NS-RAC was also evidently higher than that NAC. (4) The powdered NL was not effective in improve the bonding strength between new and old cement mortars in RAC to enhance the compressive strength because of the particle agglomeration effect. Furthermore, NL even decreased the compressive strength at the late age due to the poor dispersion of NL. Therefore, alternative effective dispersion methods are needed to improve the dispersion and reduce the particle agglomeration. (5) Colloidal NS was more effective in reducing the micro-scale pores and the water absorption of NS-modified RAC compared to powdered NL-modified RAC. Although the NL could reduce the capillary-pores by physical filling effect, it was still unable to obviously reduce the macro-pores, and to increase the compressive strength of NL-modified RAC.

sections.text: The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial support of the Australian Research Council (DE150101751) and Australian Research Council Research Hub for Nanoscience Based Construction Materials Manufacturing (IH150100006). The authors are also grateful for the financial supports of the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51408210) and University of Technology Sydney Early Career Researcher Grant, Australia. The constructive suggestions and comments from Professor Surendra P. Shah at Northwestern University, USA are greatly appreciated.

referenceMentions.context: Because the properties of the recycled aggregate to a large extent determines the performances of the RAC [6,7], increasing number of studies were carried out to improve the quality of recycled aggregate.

Because the properties of the recycled aggregate to a large extent determines the performances of the RAC [6,7], increasing number of studies were carried out to improve the quality of recycled aggregate.
These methods include microwave heating [8], chemical immersion [9], biological precipitation [10,11], carbonization [12,13], and surface treatment of recycled aggregate [14–17].

Therefore, it implies that the NS increased the C-S-H gel formation as a result of the reaction between NS and calcium hydroxide (CH) and filled the spaces in the C-S-H crystal lattice as physical nano-fillers [46,47].
This indicates that NS modification of RAC was mainly due to the secondary chemical reaction, while just slightly due to the physical filling effect [5].
